Author: Perrard, A.
Title: Observations on the colony activity of the asian hornet vespa velutina lepeletier 1836 (hymenoptera: Vespidae: Vespinae) in france
Journal: Annales de la Societe entomologique de France (N.S.)
outcome_apis_predation: Captive colony: 25-50 honeybees/day (mean 37.5). Free-living nests: 84.8% of flesh pellets (145/171) were Apis mellifera thoraxes
outcome_other_apis_behavior: attacks throughout day with peak in morning
outcome_predation_time_of_the_day: average 4 trials needed to catch honeybee

Author: Monceau, K.
Title: Predation pressure dynamics study of the recently introduced honeybee killer Vespa velutina : learning from the enemy
distance_hornets_nest: Predation lasted 5 months. ART site: 916 hornets trapped
outcome_apis_predation: VIL site: 1894 hornets trapped. Predation affected by wind speed, temperature, humidity. Peak captures: 106 (ART) and 217 (VIL) on 12 Nov

Author: Monceau, K.
Title: Native prey and invasive predator patterns of foraging activity: The case of the yellow-legged hornet predation at european honeybee hives.
distance_hornets_nest: Video monitoring of 2 hives. Predation pressure increased during season. Number of honeybee captures showed maximum peak for intermediate number of V. velutina. Captures increased during midday hours

Author: Monceau, K.
Title: Spatial distribution of Vespa velutina individuals hunting at domestic honeybee hives: heterogeneity at a local scale
distance_hornets_nest: Capture-mark-recapture study. 360 hornets captured and tagged. More than 50% marked hornets recaptured. Estimated 350 hornets visiting patch daily. 88% recaptured in front of different hives but distribution was aggregative

Author: Arca, M.
Title: Defensive behaviour of Apis mellifera against Vespa velutina in France: Testing whether European honeybees can develop an effective collective defence against a new predator
n_vespa_velutina: Investigated 8 apiaries and 95 colonies. A. mellifera in France exhibit inefficient and unorganized defence against V. velutina. Colonies subjected to either low or high levels of predation

Author: Monceau, K.
Title: Daily and seasonal extranidal behaviour variations in the invasive yellow-legged hornet, vespa velutina lepeletier (hymenoptera: Vespidae)
distance_hornets_nest: Video monitoring of two colonies during growth from August to November. Three major behaviours monitored: nest maintenance, patrolling on nest, foraging flights

Author: Monceau, K.
Title: How apis mellifera behaves with its invasive hornet predator vespa velutina
n_vespa_velutina: Video monitoring of two hives. Balling behaviour reported for first time under natural conditions in A. mellifera against V. velutina. Number of hornets impacted honeybee foraging and defence behaviours

Author: Budge, G.
Title: The invasion, provenance and diversity of vespa velutina lepeletier (hymenoptera: Vespidae) in great britain
distance_hornets_nest: First report in Great Britain. Single nest in Gloucestershire. Foraging activity largely restricted within 700m of nest

Author: Jacques, M.
Title: A pan-European epidemiological study reveals honey bee colony survival depends on beekeeper education and disease control
n_vespa_velutina: Pan-European study. Overwinter losses ranged 2-32%. High summer losses likely to follow high winter losses. Hobbyist beekeepers had double winter mortality compared to professionals

Author: Poidatz, J.
Title: Activity rhythm and action range of workers of the invasive hornet predator of honeybees Vespa velutina, measured by radio frequency identification tags.
outcome_apis_predation: RFID study. Homing ability up to 5000m. Foraging range estimated ca. 1000m around nest. Most flight activity 07:00-20:00. 318 individuals released at different distances, 71 individuals monitored 24/24 for 2 months

Author: Courtois, P.
Title: A cost-benefit approach for prioritizing invasive species
distance_hornets_nest: Theoretical framework for prioritization. Mentions V. velutina: from 2 nests in 2004 to 1613 nests in 2007, covering 150000 km2 in 2008. No coordinated control policy implemented as of 2009

Author: Requier, F.
Title: Predation of the invasive Asian hornet affects foraging activity and survival probability of honey bees in Western Europe
distance_hornets_nest: Field observations and model simulations. Evidence of bee foragers' homing failures and foraging paralysis. Hornet-induced disturbances affect colony dynamics and winter survival. Foraging paralysis is important mechanism underlying winter colony collapse

Author: Leza, M.
Title: The impact of the invasive species Vespa velutina on honeybees: A new approach based on oxidative stress.
Journal: The Science of the total environment

Author: Requier, F.
Title: A biodiversity-friendly method to mitigate the invasive Asian hornet's impact on European honey bees
distance_hornets_nest: Tested beehive muzzle on 22 pairs of colonies. Muzzle did not reduce homing failure but drastically reduced foraging paralysis. Increased survival probability up to 51% in high hornet abundance context

Author: Gregorc, A.
Title: Monitoring of honey bee colony losses: a special issue

Author: Barbet-Massin, M.
Title: The economic cost of control of the invasive yellow-legged Asian hornet
Journal: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions
distance_hornets_nest: Nest destruction cost €23 million 2006-2015 in France. Yearly cost increasing. Could reach €11.9M (France), €9.0M (Italy), €8.6M (UK) if species fills climatically suitable distribution

Author: Renault, D.
Title: Biological invasions in France: Alarming costs and even more alarming knowledge gaps
Journal: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions

Author: Verdasca, M. J.
Title: A metabarcoding tool to detect predation of the honeybee Apis mellifera and other wild insects by the invasive Vespa velutina

Author: Angulo, E.
Title: Economic costs of invasive alien species in Spain
Journal: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions

Author: Rome, Q.
Title: Not just honeybees: predatory habits of Vespa velutina (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) in France
Journal: Annales de la Societe entomologique de France (N.S.)
distance_hornets_nest: Studied 16 nests. Identified 2151 prey pellets. Generalist predator: honeybees 38.1%, flies 29.9%, social wasps 19.7%, 159+ species. Urban colonies prey more on honeybees, forest colonies more on wasps. Peak predation early October. Single nest consumes average 11.32 kg insect biomass/season

Author: Dieguez-Anton, A.
Title: Monitoring study in honeybee colonies stressed by the invasive hornet vespa velutina.

Author: Rojas-Nossa, S. V.
Title: Effectiveness of electric harps in reducing Vespa velutina predation pressure and consequences for honey bee colony development.

Author: Bouzar, C.
Title: Chemical and genetic evidences that multiple hornet colonies attack honeybee colonies

Author: Lioy, S.
Title: The invasive hornet Vespa velutina : distribution, impacts and management options

Author: Poidatz, J.
Title: Density of predating Asian hornet's at hives disturbs the 3D flight performance of honey bees and decreases predation success.

Author: O'Shea-Wheller, T. A.
Title: Quantifying the impact of an invasive hornet on bombus terrestris colonies.

Author: Stainton, K.
Title: Molecular identification of asian hornet vespa velutina nigrithorax prey from larval gut contents: a promising method to study the diet of an invasive pest.
Journal: Animals : an open access journal from MDPI

Author: Perez-Granados, C.
Title: Testing the selectiveness of electric harps: a mitigation method for reducing Asian hornet impact at beehives

Author: Minaud, E.
Title: How stressors disrupt honey bee biological traits and overwintering mechanisms.

Author: Dieguez-Anton, A.
Title: Management of honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) colonies under yellow-legged hornet (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) pressure

Author: Pedersen, S.
Title: Broad ecological threats of an invasive hornet revealed through a deep sequencing approach.
Journal: The Science of the total environment

Author: Herrera, C.
Title: Assessing predation pressure of Vespa velutina on local fauna through DNA metabarcoding

Author: Dieguez-Anton, A.
Title: Long-term Vespa velutina nigrithorax pressure: Honey bee risk survival to alien invasion
